talk.start.para: .- I congratulate the Prime Minister on having performed a task which certainly ranks amongst the severest that can be imposed on the Leader of the Government, or upon any member of the Ministry who may be charged with it. I am indebted to the right honorable gentleman for a copy of the figures which he has used in his remarks. They lay before me during the course of the speech, and enabled me to follow him with much greater ease.

speech.para: We may all take heart of grace sincerely rejoicing at the tale of prosperity which it has fallen to the lot of the Prime Minister to place before the people of the country. On great national issues we are simply citizens of Australia, and citizens of the Empire. Every figure which the Prime Minister read, pointing to our progress - most, if not all of them, we believe to be well-based, and full of propitious promises for the future - appeal to the whole of us as demonstrating what we have always been proud to proclaim, though some have been loth to accept - the enormous potential wealth of Australia - its immense actual wealth today, and its boundless prospective increase in the future. Consequently, the rejoicing is no more on one side than it is on the other in respect to the growth which we have to record. The outlook is exceedingly encouraging in every regard, and no word shall fall from me which would tend to belittle it in any way.

It is one constitutional duty of the members of the Opposition to bring to bear on the material put before us by the Treasurer the best analytical faculty we possess, to discover what there is in his statement to content us, and the directions in which we should walk warily. The method of presenting the national balance-sheet and outlining the Government policy hitherto followed leaves much to be desired. I was not sufficiently disorderly to interrupt my right honorable friend by suggesting that his tables be taken as read ; but it would be better if, earlier in the day of the delivery of a Budget, a printed digest of the main features were put before honorable members, so that they could grasp the issues involved. The Treasurer could then devote himself to an analysis of the tables, and an exposition of the great questions of policy with which he had to deal.

talk.start.para: - I understand that tables must be read to get them into Hansard.

- If an alteration of our rules be necessary to do what I suggest, it should be made this session, so that, when we next listen to my right honorable friend, he may be free to speak without an embarrassing mass of detail, such as that through which he had to pick his way to-night. He devoted much more time to mere lists of figures than to the important statements of policy we were awaiting. His elucidation of the problems before us, and examination of alternatives, was consequently so curtailed that, until we have had leisure to read his speech, we shall not be able to apply ourselves with advantage to a real criticism of the proposals omitted or embodied in it. The same complaint has been made year after year. It is unfair to all Treasurers that they should only have time to give a partial sketch of the financial situation. Until we have studied the mass of material laid before us, even striking and suggestive indications of national growth or decline will pass without the scrutiny and appreciation which is their due.

speech.para: Hence I do not now pretend to offer either a financial policy speech, or even the full criticism which the speech of the Treasurer deserves. Speaking impromptu, and with only an imperfect recollection of the long lists of figures to which we listened for more than an hour and a half, let me first draw attention, for the better realization of our position, to some special circumstances which the right honorable gentleman not unnaturally ignored. An extraordinary transformation of the financial situation was accomplished at the time the present Government took office, due to the expiration of the bookkeeping period, during which the hands of Parliament had been tied. Synchronizing with this was an entire change of policy introduced by this Government in the distribution of the Customs revenue. These account for our credit balance.

A glance at Hansard reminds me that, although the Budget was delivered last year in September - the Treasurer apologized then, as he did to-night, for his delay - there was no chance of criticising it till November, shortly before the prorogation. As a financial transition, for this and other reasons, last session stands alone. There was a most miraculous precision in last year's forecast, the receipts and expenditure alike being estimated at exactly £16,841,629. That was the most . daring forecast ever made by a Treasurer. His receipts, in fact, amounted to £2,000,000 more than that estimate. To be fair to the right honorable gentleman, I will assume that this indicated his intention to take a. perfectly safe course by setting down his income as just sufficient to cover his expenditure. He was fortunate in knowing pretty well what he would spend, and quite aware that his revenue would far more than cover the amount.

In his first year, he shows a surplus of a little over £2,000,000. That is a very happy position of affairs. He was at pains, and very properly, to appeal to our national sentiment by sf owing that, out of the lavish resources at his command, he is providing adequately for defence. On questions of broad policy he will have the whole House behind him ; criticism of his defence proposals will be only on matters of detail. He told us that the new expenditure on defence would be about £4.750.000.

There is, in addition, a. sum due thence which cannot be assessed. Two decisions of the High Court very much reduced the receipts from the tax, and rendered it less burdensome to the landholders. Last year we were dealing with figures, then regarded as remarkably high, showing a revenue of between £16,000,000 and £1 7,000,000. This year we are on the verge of a revenue of £20,000,000, and there is no sign of decline. The revenue of the Commonwealth for future years may probably be assessed at £20,000,000. Those of us who recollect the first beginnings of this Commonwealth, ten years ago, the scrutiny to which Sir George Turner's financial proposals were subjected, though only half the same totals to-day, and the wary manner in which we walked before spending a single penny upon any public undertaking, cannot help being struck by the absolute change. To-day we are speaking lightly of a revenue of £20,000,000. Listening to the golden story unfolded by the Treasurer, we might well be forgiven if we privily pinched ourselves to make sure that we were quite awake.

talk.start.para: - We had to return three-fourths of our Customs and Excise revenue to the States, and we had no land tax in those days.
- Quite so. I think the laughter of honorable members opposite is most unbecoming.
- I do not see much sense in it myself.
- No ; they do not realize what our financial trials were in those days.
- They have not been taxed.
- It is a case of defective sympathies.
- We have put a tax on the men who have the sacks.
- That is precisely what the Government have not done.

- I hope to restore my right honorable friend's customary geniality by calling his attention to the fact that our previous Administration had the privilege of securing a recognition of the right of Australia to the profits of its own silver coinage, which had been so many years denied to us. The profit from, that coinage amounts this year to £183,000, while the Treasurer's cautious estimate for next year is £210,000. We are thus in the position of financing the present Government - of finding the means which enable its members to indulge in outbursts of hilarity. Was there ever a more unselfish act?

speech.para: Let me now rapidly allude to some of the many omissions from the Treasurer's financial statement. One of these, which I was awaiting most anxiously, was dealt with by the right honorable gentleman at the last moment. I think the Committee would have willingly forgiven him had he trespassed upon our patience by giving a frank exposition of the views of the Government, and of the course they are pursuing, in relation to the great operation of the consolidation of the State debts, which we have been so long attempting to handle. He has told us nothing really pertinent. Six or seven years have elapsed since I had the privilege of meeting the Premiers of the States, endeavouring to arrive at an agreement on that all important matter. My endeavour, like some that preceded, and others that followed it, was unsuccessful. But even at that time the Premiers had become impressed with the fact that propositions were being sub- mittted,on the part of the Commonwealth, which promised well to them, and would be in the future better than anything for which they could hope until they united with us in pooling our financial credit. It was all very well, while the Commonwealth was still in its infantile stages, to point to the great wealth and prosperity of the several States, and their perfect ability to stand alone. No one 'questioned it. What was questioned was whether they were obtaining, or, at all events, could continue to obtain, the best terms possible. What could not be questioned was that the credit of Australia as a whole must necessarily stand higher than that of any portion of Australia; and that, in the course of time, that fact must more and more assert itself. Consequently, for years we pressed the States very eagerly and very anxiously in this regard, making suggestion after suggestion in order to arrive at an agreement. However little was accomplished, certainly something was achieved. The way was not only opened, but well paved before we left office ; and I cannot but believe that if the Prime Minister and his colleagues had continued to press the matter during the whole period they have been in power we should have had a. much more encouraging progress report than we have had to-night.

talk.start.para: - I have never looked upon the question as being a party one.

- It is not; it is not even Federal in the sense of relating only to this Parliament. This is an Australian question, affecting every citizen, and embracing every one of its Governments. The Prime Minister and his colleagues must surely have made up their minds, on the information afforded to them, as to what, in their opinion, is the best plan to follow. Yet what have they done?
- They will find it more difficult than they thought it was.

- At all events, they should present the best plan that the circumstances permit. It is not necessary that we should know just what it is ; nor do we desire, at this stage, to be made aware of details ; but if we had been assured that practical communications had been passing between the Commonwealth Government and the State Governments on some general basis that we could approve, such an intimation would have been welcomed by the people of Australia. They are looking forward eagerly to a settlement of this question and will richly reward with their approval those who may be fortunate enough while in office to make a proposition that can be generally accepted.
- I have had many personal conversations, which are as good as anything else in these matters.

- Personal conversations with those concerned are valuable if they lead up to or formulate a plan of joint action which will provide for our mutual interests and development. But they may mean nothing at all. The Governments with which I have been associated obtained the best knowledge that was available in one of the world's financial centres - London - and thought we saw our way to proposals that the States would accept. If the Treasurer will take up the negotiations where we left them, and perfect our proposals, they will receive any assistance that we can give them. This is in no sense a party question, its settlement would be one of the best things that has ever been done by the Ministry or the House.
- Subject to further consideration I have no objection to a Committee from both sides of the House to deal with the whole question.
- I welcome that proposal, and at once pass in some haste from that subject to matters that seem to be unwisely regarded as minor.

speech.para: I heard no encouraging references in the Treasurer's statement to the policy of the Bounties Acts, which the present Ministry found on the statute-book when they took office. I heard no warm- appreciation of that policy, and no evidence of an attempt to extend it. Indeed, I heard no record of progress beyond that which would have taken place in the ordinary course of events. This suggests that there is not behind these proposals for the encouragement of particular native industries, which can be reached only in that way, all the zest, warmth, and vigour that we need and desire. I venture to say that some reference, at all events, in this direction was to be expected in a statement of national policy.

Then, again, the Prime Minister has said in this House that he and his colleagues are anxious that certain preferential trade agreements should be brought about between_ Australia, and New Zealand, and Canada, as well as with South Africa, with whom we had the good fortune to make an agreement that has been profitable to this country. But, although such trade agreements form an important part of the financial policy of the Commonwealth, and were earnestly sought by us, we find that they,, too, are relegated to some future period.

Then comes the most striking omission of all. Except for a judicious reference to the development of settlement in the Northern Territory, no allusion was made by the Prime Minister, in his policy speech, to necessary developments of our whole immigration system, even those required to meet demands that have been, officially indorsed by representatives of all parties in the States. Industrials, who look at the question from opposite sides, have agreed that thousands of new employs are absolutely required for many industries and callings. We have this appeal for more life-blood for Australia, which I am sure all Australians desire, but save in the relation mentioned the subject finds no place amongst the propositions that have been submitted to us to-night.

No circumstances of industrial unrest by which we are surrounded can have any bearing upon this problem on any scale with which it is possible for us to deal at present. If we were within a day or two's sail of the Old World, and were entering upon an unconsidered scheme of wholesale immigration, we might easily go wrong. But having regard to our poor means of communication with Great Britain, the long distances to be traversed, the cost and delay involved, it is plain that if we used every available vessel to bring, immigrants to the different portions of Australia - and there are many - where there is a keen demand for settlers to join in the development of this country, we could not over-supply them-. In the circumstances the least we can do is to make a spirited response to the complaints of intending immigrants, giving some evidence that efforts are being made to utilize the ships coming to our shores from civilized countries to increase our numbers, subject to the regulation of our Acts. Any policy that omits this cardinal factor ignores and' imperils the future. The Prime Minister has clearly recognised by implication throughout his speech that the necessary and natural consequence of our Federal action is now bearing fruit to such an extent that the demand for white men 'and white women must intensify all over this continent in an increasingly rapid degree. Why then, does his Cabinet stand still ?

It is most unfortunate, also, that the Prime Minister, by his studied silence, gave us no encouragement to hope that they are making any endeavour to meet even the obvious flagrant and glaring anomalies that have been discovered in the Tariff, in respect of which we appealed to the House last year. We have neither the employes to meet the present demands here or in prospect from Britain.

talk.start.para: - The matter was mentioned in the Governor-General's Speech. As the honorable member knows, it would not be judicious to mention Tariff alterations in a Budget statement unless we were going to do something.

- But I want the Government to do something now. I was about to remind the Committee that there was a reference in the Governor-General's Speech that had kindled a good deal of expectation. Tariff proposals, as they affect the Treasury, are peculiarly within the province of the Treasurer. It has been the invariable practice to make some allusion in the Budget statement to the general intentions of the Government, so far as it would be wise to disclose them, at all events, in their effect upon revenue.
- Does the honorable member think that would be the right thing to do?
- I do.
- I think not. When the Government are ready, it is a different matter.
- They should be ready now. I have been accustomed, both in State and Federal experience, to hear the Treasurers of the day announce whether they proposed or not to deal with Tariff questions.
- I shall never do it.
- Is that not rather an unwise thing to do?

- If there are any unwise disclosures in this speech, they are not of that character. Something might be said about the particular information regarding our defences. That was much more unwise than any disclosures about our financial or industrial prospects.
- The only disclosure is that the Treasurer anticipates a larger amount of revenue from the Customs.

- That means no Tariff alteration, even in the direction of remedying admitted abuses. I would not dream of saying that the Treasurer should give a hint as to the precise direction in which he proposed to go.
- If the Treasurer made any announcement, it would enable importers to take advantage of the position.

- I doubt it. Considering the period we - have reached in this session, it would make very little difference. They could not get the goods here before the necessary resolution protecting the revenue was laid on the table of the House.
- It would lead to speculation, anyhow.

- We cannot help speculating about it. This is a pressing need which is continually brought before us, and which is being keenly felt. The sooner the Government make up their minds what they are prepared to do on the question, and do it, the sooner will come a respite from this costly uncertainty. However disappointed people in business may be with what will be done, at all events they will know where they are for another year or two. That would be a great advantage. The omission of any such assurance is one of the most grave and serious of all the omissions in the speech. It must be kept continually before us till it is dealt with.

speech.para: I did not anticipate that the Prime Minister would to-night unfold his proposal in relation to the Commonwealth Bank, as that will be dealt with in the measure of which he has given notice. But I did think that the policy of that bank, and its place in our financial future, so far as he foresees it at the moment, would have been indicated in some general fashion, so that we could see how it was linked up to those particular enterprises which it is intended to foster and support. We should have had in that direction, also, some general guidance for the public, and enabling honorable members to commence to give a proposal of this magnitude the close and careful attention it deserves.

We still find that our appeals for the establishment of an Inter-State Commission are disregarded. That body is authorized by our Constitution, and its functions, quite irrespective of some that we proposed to add, are of the utmost importance. I regret that we hear nothing in regard to its appointment. The Treasurer referred to that most interesting Imperial Commission which is to visit the various portions of the Empire, and report upon their resources. Personally, I regret that this inquiry is crippled by the exclusion of any investigation into the fiscal circumstances and policies of the different Dominions. Most valuable will be the information which is to be sought by the Commission. Its collocation will occupy a considerable time. The report must be exhaustive in order to be useful, and should be immensely valuable to us when we get the result of its labours regarding ourselves, our fellow Dominions in the Empire, and the Empire generally. But the value of its work would have been much more enhanced if it had been accompanied by an analysis and study of the Tariff and Excise duties levied in each and every part of the Empire. That, and other information of the kind, would have been very pertinent in explaining to us our special developments in some cases, and our failure to develop in others.

talk.start.para: - Will not the Commission take that subject into consideration?

- I regret that it was specially excluded at the request of the Home Government, whose motives, of course, can be understood. I say nothing in that regard, but in an inquiry of this sort the interests of the Dominions count for a larger factor in some senses than even those of the Mother Country. After all, the resources, and capacities, and circumstances of Great Britain are known to an extent that as to the outer Dominions we cannot approach. Relatively, we are unknown. Full fiscal inquiries ought to be made at least in regard to us, and would have been extremely valuable when made.

speech.para: The Inter-State Commission ought to do for Australia what that Commission is authorized to do, as far as it can in the circumstances for the Empire as a whole. Our Inter-State Commission ought to have been appointed some time back. We could not. then find a House willing to face the relatively trifling extra cost involved, in order that Australia as a whole might be systematically studied, and its data carefully collected, and authenticated. With its guidance in our industrial and other Courts, in our statistics, and in our legislation, we should have before us the essential facts relating to the people, the products, the prosperity, and the general circumstances of Australia. These would enable us to proceed with a confidence which we cannot now possess, because those data have not been properly, collected, sifted, and made available. While, therefore, I rejoice in the appointment of the limited Imperial Commission, I regret very much the absence of the Inter-State Commission, and the work it would have undertaken for us.

The Minister of External Affairs will find in this House, and during this session, a very earnest desire to have much fuller information than the Treasurer could be expected to give us yet in regard to the Northern Territory, Papua, and other outlying portions in which we are so deeply interested. The general outline given by the Treasurer is satisfactory as far as it goes, but it requires to be enormously supplemented and made real to us, so that this House and the country may come right behind the Minister, as I hope they will do in the circumstances, and give him every assistance. That is another of these non-party questions to which I have endeavoured to devote the few minutes for which I have ventured to trespass upon the time of. the Committee. But really in all matters of high policy we are left in the clark.

With more leisure, more means of comparison, and more data at" hand, it will be our duty to analyze thoroughly the details of the various important matters of expenditure and investment which the Treasurer has outlined. As they stand, the two or three outstanding facts which have impressed themselves on us to-night show that our revenue is abundant, and climbing steadily and rapidly. The causes of the rise are perfectly plain to us, and not mysterious to outsiders. Our expenditure is climbing up with it; but the outlay for purposes of national defence and other matters of that sort will be cordially supported all round the House. The question remains how far the Treasurer's speech falls short of doing the necessary justice to our industrial developments, and how many omissions there are which ought to be supplied before we can accept the financial policy as satisfactory to members on both sides of the House, and worthy of the opportunities which Australia enjoys to-day? The sooner those omissions are supplied the better. When does the Treasurer propose that the debate shall be resumed? I presume it will not be next week.

talk.start.para: - There are the Works and Buildings Estimates to go on with. . We will take the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill, and then go on with the Works Estimates.
- We do not wish to delay any works which are really matters of urgency.
- Does the' Treasurer propose to take the Works Estimates before this debate is completed?
- We generally take the Works Estimates first, sometimes on- the same night as the Budget is delivered.

- I do not know that it would be fair to take the whole of the Works Estimates. The Treasurer could obtain without a query the necessary sum for the next month .or two to carry him on with the works, and then we could plunge into the general questions of financial policy in the Budget debate.
- If we pass the Works Estimates, there is nothing much left.
- As the numbers stand, our criticism will not have any result in any case. I feel relieved of responsibility in that direction.
- I do not wish to tie the . hands of the Opposition, but I think the Works Estimates should be got through before the Budget debate.

- That is inverting the natural order of affairs. We can, of course, alter it, and there is a certain amount of interest in the endeavour to persuade honorable members opposite to do what ought to be done. We have no other weapon. If we cannot persuade, we cannot coerce. Perhaps the Treasurer will leave the question over until Tuesday.
- I shall be glad to confer with the honorable member.

- I feel that it will be unfair, both to the House and to the Treasurer, if, on the cursory acquaintance which I have been able to gain, chiefly through his kindness in providing me with this document, I were to plunge into that fuller criticism of the Budget which will become part of . our duty at a later stage. I propose to reserve any really critical or analytical remarks until then. In a general way I have tried to show the points on which we find ourselves in agreement with the spirit of the Treasurer's address and with his general proposals. Beyond these, the responsibility rests upon us of making the closest and most searching criticism of the proposals of the Government before they are passed into law. In doing that, we shall discharge our duty as an Opposition, and as representatives of the people who sent us here.

. - I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his criticism. We are always thankful as a Government for criticism, because in a matter of this kind it is perhaps much more valuable than praise. As regards the immigration question, I intended to speak upon, but over-locked, a matter closely associated with it - that is, that the first essential to the carrying on of the business of the Commonwealth overseas is a suitable building in London for the High Commissioner and for the States. The Government intend to deal with that question earnestly, so that our representatives in Great Britain may be properly equipped.
- What has that to do with immigration?

- A building worthy of the Commonwealth in London, properly equipped for the Commonwealth and the States, and with the High Commissioner and the representatives of the States housed there, would be a bigger advertisement for Australia than, perhaps, £100,000 spent in another way would be. People would learn then about Australia. .They have only to know what the' conditions of Australia are, and we shall get the best class of people to come here of .their own accord. I myself and many others did that simply through reading, the facts about the country.
- How long before the building is complete?
- It may be done in a year.
- Building and everything?'

- Yes, at the rate at which things are done now. If the land has to be purchased and the building has to be erected, at a cost amounting to about two-thirds of a million - that would be for a proper substantial .property - the money would have to be provided in one .year.
- Is the honorable member taking authority to expend that money in these Estimates ?
- No; we shall have to proceed by a Bill to deal with a matter of that kind.
- It will be three years before the work is finished.

- I hope not.' I shall be glad to take into consideration with my colleagues the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition regarding the Inter-State, Commission. I think there is something in: what he said. I do not agree at all with the honorable member's proposition that we should make a statement at this stage about the Tariff. When there is any Tariff revision it should be carried out when the Government are ready, and without any intimation.
- Is it proposed to make any special grant to Tasmania ?

- The Government have not yet considered the report of the Royal Commission, as a Government, and they do not wish to prejudice the report in any way by expressing an opinion. I have no hesitation in' saying on my own- account hat any appeal under section 96 of the Constitution by the Government of Tasmania must receive consideration.
- How is it proposed to spend the ^£22,000 on the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta railway?
- That is the whole of the money that the expert engineer desired for this year. If it is not enough the engineer can have as much more as is necessary to hurry the work.

speech.para: Progress reported.
